title: landscapemetrics
text:
Homepage





Calculates landscape metrics for categorical landscape patterns in a tidy workflow. ‘landscapemetrics’ reimplements the most common metrics from ‘FRAGSTATS’ and new ones from the current literature on landscape metrics. This package supports ‘raster’ spatial objects and takes RasterLayer, RasterStacks, RasterBricks or lists of RasterLayer from the ‘raster’ package as input arguments. It further provides utility functions to visualize patches, select metrics and building blocks to develop new metrics.

title: spectre
text:
Homepage





Predict regional community composition at a fine spatial resolution using only sparse biological and environmental data. The package is based on the DynamicFOAM algorithm described in Mokany et al. (2011)

title: onpoint
text:
Homepage





Growing collection of small helper functions for point pattern analysis. Most functions are designed to work with the spatstat package.

title: M.H.K. Hesselbarth
text:
Maximilian H.K. Hesselbarth   (he/him) 
 Computational Ecologist  ||  Data Scientist  ||  R programmer 
        
 Biography 
Hi, my name is Max, and I am a computational ecologist by training and a data scientist at the Energy and Environment section of Statistics Austria. For more information about my background, please refer to my CV.



Feel free to reach out anytime if you’re interested in my past or current work.

title: NLMR
text:
Homepage





‘NLMR’ combines a large number of algorithms from other published software for simulating neutral landscapes. The simulation results are obtained in a spatial data format (raster* objects from the ‘raster’ package) and can, therefore, be used in any sort of raster data operation that is performed with standard observation data.

title: shar
text:
Homepage





Analyse species-habitat associations in R. Therefore, information about the location of the species is needed and about the environmental conditions. To test for significance habitat associations, one of the two components is randomized. Methods are mainly based on Plotkin et al. (2000) and Harms et al. (2001).
